title-group.article-title: Weak values of a quantum observable and the cross-Wigner distribution

abstract.p: We study the weak values of a quantum observable from the point of view of the Wigner formalism. The main actor here is the cross-Wigner transform of two functions, which is in disguise the cross-ambiguity function familiar from radar theory and time-frequency analysis. It allows us to express weak values using a complex probability distribution. We suggest that our approach seems to confirm that the weak value of an observable is, as conjectured by several authors, due to the interference of two wavefunctions, one coming from the past, and the other from the future.

abstract.title: Highlights
abstract.p: ► Application of the cross-Wigner transform to a redefinition of the weak value of a quantum observable. ► Phase space approach to weak values, associated with a complex probability distribution. ► Opens perspectives for the study of retrodiction.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: We study in the present Letter the notion of weak measurement introduced by Aharonov and Albert [2], Bergmann, and Lebowitz in [1–6] from the point of view of the Wigner phase space formalism. This will allow us to discuss the claim made by these authors that the weak value can be seen as the interference of two wavepackets, one going forward in time and the other backwards in time.

Let us briefly recall the difference between an ideal (also called strong, or von Neumann) measurement, and a weak measurement. Let Aˆ be a (quantum) observable, realized as an essentially self-adjoint operator; we assume for simplicity that Aˆ has eigenvalues a1, a2, …a1,a2,… with corresponding orthogonal eigenfunctions ψ1, ψ2, …ψ1,ψ2,… . In an ideal measurement the expectation value of Aˆ in a pre-selected state ψ is(1)〈Aˆ〉ψ=〈ψ|Aˆ|ψ〉〈ψ|ψ〉; if the sequence of eigenvalues lies in some interval [amin, amax][amin,amax] then we will have amin⩽〈Aˆ〉ψ⩽amax. In fact, if one performs the ideal measurement the outcome will always be one of the eigenvalues λjλj, and the probability of this outcome is |λj|2 / ‖ψj‖2|λj|2/‖ψj‖2 where λjλj is the coefficient of ψjψj in the Fourier expansion ψ = ∑ jλjψjψ=∑jλjψj. Moreover the system will be left in the state ψjψj after the ideal measurement yielding the value ajaj. The situation is very different for weak measurements. As is explained in Ritchie et al. [26] (also see Berry and Shukla [9], Steinberg [28]), in a weak measurement the eigenvalues are not fully resolved and the system is left in a superposition of the unresolved states. If an appropriate post-selection is made, this superposition can interfere to produce a measurement result which can be significantly outside the range of the eigenvalues of the observable Aˆ. This is achieved by making the coupling with the measuring device so small that the change of quantum state due to the interaction can be neglected. The post-selection can then be accomplished by making an ideal measurement of some other observable Bˆ and selecting one particular outcome. Thus, the post-selected state |ϕ〉|ϕ〉 is an eigenstate of Bˆ which can be expressed as a linear combination of the eigenstates of Aˆ (we note that, conversely, an ideal measurement can be expressed as a convex sum of weak values: see Hosoya and Shikano [22]). If 〈ϕ|ψ〉 ≠ 0〈ϕ|ψ〉≠0 (and if ϕ, ψ are square integrable) the weak value of Aˆ is then the complex number(2)〈Aˆ〉weakϕ,ψ=〈ϕ|Aˆ|ψ〉〈ϕ|ψ〉. The readings of the pointer of the measuring device will cluster around Re〈Aˆ〉weakϕ,ψ while Im〈Aˆ〉weakϕ,ψ measures the shift in the variable conjugate to the pointer variable; see Aharonov and Vaidman [5] for a detailed exposition.

We will show that this weak value can be expressed in terms of the cross-Wigner transform(3)W(ϕ,ψ)(x,p)=(12πℏ)N∫RNe−iℏpyϕ⁎(x+12y)ψ(x−12y)dy of the pair (ϕ, ψ)(ϕ,ψ) whose physical interpretation is that of an interference term in the Wigner distribution of the sum ϕ + ψϕ+ψ; we mention that the importance of these interference terms has been emphasized and studied by Zurek [31] in the context of the sub-Planckian structures in phase space. The cross-Wigner transform is a very important object being intensively studied in the harmonic analysis literature and in time-frequency analysis; see e.g. Cohen [11], Folland [14], Gröchenig [17], Hlawatsch and Flandrin [21]. The cross-Wigner transform W(ϕ, ψ)(x, p)W(ϕ,ψ)(x,p) reduces to the familiar Wigner distribution (Hillery et al. [20], Littlejohn [23]) when ϕ = ψϕ=ψ. (Observe that our definition (3) of W(ϕ, ψ)W(ϕ,ψ) is the opposite of the definition used in mathematical texts, where ϕ⁎ϕ⁎ is replaced with ϕ and ψ with ψ⁎ψ⁎; both definitions are simply complex conjugate of each other.)

We will not address here the ontological debates arising around the problem of “Elements of Reality” (Cohen and Hiley [12,13]), Vaidman [29]); these epistemological questions are difficult and have led to profound philosophical controversies.

Notation. We will work with systems having N degrees of freedom. Position (respectively momentum) variables are denoted x = (x1, …, xN)x=(x1,…,xN) (resp. p = (p1, …, pN)p=(p1,…,pN)); they are vectors in ℝNRN. The corresponding phase space variable is z = (x, p)z=(x,p); it is a vector in phase space ℝ2NR2N. We will endow the phase space with the standard symplectic form σ(z, z′) = px′ − p′xσ(z,z′)=px′−p′x. When integrating we will use, where appropriate, the volume elements dx = dx1 ⋯ dxNdx=dx1⋯dxN, dp = dp1 ⋯ dpNdp=dp1⋯dpN, dz = dp dxdz=dpdx. The unitary ℏ-Fourier transform of a function ψ in L2(ℝN)L2(RN) is defined byFψ(p)=(12πℏ)N/2∫RNe−iℏpyψ(y)dy.

sec.title: A complex probability distribution
sec.p: The cross-Wigner transform (3) satisfies the “marginal properties”(4)∫RNW(ϕ,ψ)(z)dp=ϕ(x)⁎ψ(x) and(5)∫RNW(ϕ,ψ)(z)dx=Fϕ(p)⁎Fψ(p). It follows from the equality (4) that(6)∫RNW(ϕ,ψ)(z)dz=〈ϕ|ψ〉.

For 〈ϕ|ψ〉 ≠ 0〈ϕ|ψ〉≠0 we define(7)ρϕ,ψ(z)=W(ϕ,ψ)(z)〈ϕ|ψ〉. Note the conjugation relation ρϕ, ψ(z)⁎ = ρψ, ϕ(z)ρϕ,ψ(z)⁎=ρψ,ϕ(z); also ρλϕ, λψ(z) = ρϕ, ψ(z)ρλϕ,λψ(z)=ρϕ,ψ(z) for every complex λ ≠ 0λ≠0 hence the function ρϕ, ψρϕ,ψ only depends on the states |ψ〉|ψ〉 and |ϕ〉|ϕ〉. In view of Eq. (6) we have(8)∫R2Nρϕ,ψ(z)dz=1 hence ρϕ, ψρϕ,ψ can be viewed as a complex probability distribution with respect to which the average of the classical observable A is calculated; also, Eq. (8) implies that(9)∫R2NReρϕ,ψ(z)dz=1,∫R2NImρϕ,ψ(z)dz=0 so that Re ρϕ, ψReρϕ,ψ can be viewed as a quasi-distribution, in the same way as the usual Wigner transform. When ψ = ϕψ=ϕ then Im ρψ, ψ = 0Imρψ,ψ=0 and Re ρψ, ψ = WψReρψ,ψ=Wψ. Observe that it immediately follows from Eqs. (7) and (4), (5) that the marginals distributions of ρϕ, ψρϕ,ψ are given by(10)∫RNρϕ,ψ(z)dp=ϕ⁎(x)ψ(x)〈ϕ|ψ〉,∫RNρϕ,ψ(z)dx=[Fϕ(p)]⁎Fψ(p)〈ϕ|ψ〉; note that anyone of these equalities allows by integrating in the conjugate variable to recover the normalization condition (8).

We point out that the consideration of complex probability densities has per se nothing unusual; such complex probabilities have been used in the context of stochastic processes (see Zak [30]), signal theory (multipath fading channels, see Chayawan [10]) and they also appear in the study of non-Hermitian quantum mechanics (see Barkay and Moiseyev [8]).

We claim that: Theorem 1
Let A be a classical observable andAˆits Weyl quantization; we have(11)〈Aˆ〉weakϕ,ψ=∫R2NA(z)ρϕ,ψ(z)dz.

The reader familiar with the Weyl–Wigner–Moyal formalism (de Gosson [15,16], Littlejohn [23]) will have noticed that when ϕ = ψϕ=ψ formula (11) reduces to the well-known relation〈ψ|Aˆ|ψ〉=∫R2NA(z)Wψ(z)dz yielding the usual expectation value 〈Aˆ〉ψ=〈ψ|Aˆ|ψ〉/〈ψ|ψ〉. We will study the relative importance of these values when ϕ and ψ are coherent states in Section 2.3.

sec.title: Proof of Theorem 1
sec.p: To prove formula (11) it is sufficient, in view of definition (7) of ρϕ, ψ(z)ρϕ,ψ(z), to show that(12)〈ϕ|Aˆ|ψ〉=∫R2NW(ϕ,ψ)(z)A(z)dz. To prove the latter we could perform a direct calculation staring from the right-hand side, inserting the expression (3) of W(ϕ, ψ)(z)W(ϕ,ψ)(z) and making various changes of variables. We prefer to give a more elegant proof which has some conceptual advantages. The first step consists in observing that the cross-Wigner transform can be expressed in terms of the Grossmann–Royer [18,27] operator(13)TˆGR(z0)ϕ(x)=e2iℏp0(x−x0)ϕ(2x0−x) (also see de Gosson [16, Chapter 9]). A simple calculation shows that we have(14)W(ϕ,ψ)(z)=(1πℏ)N〈TˆGR(z)ϕ|ψ〉 and that the Weyl quantization Aˆ of the observable is given by(15)Aˆψ(x)=(1πℏ)N∫R2NA(z0)TˆGR(z0)ψ(x)dz0. Using the latter we have(16)〈ϕ|Aˆ|ψ〉=(1πℏ)N∫R2NA(z0)〈ϕ|TˆGR(z0)ψ〉dz0; we next observe that TˆGR(z0) is both unitary and involutive (i.e. TˆGR(z0)=TˆGR(z0)−1) and hence(17)〈ϕ|TˆGR(z0)ψ〉=〈TˆGR(z0)−1ϕ|ψ〉=〈TˆGR(z0)ϕ|ψ〉 so that (16) can be rewritten〈ϕ|Aˆ|ψ〉=(1πℏ)N∫R2NA(z0)〈TˆGR(z0)ϕ|ψ〉dz0=∫R2NA(z0)W(ϕ,ψ)(z)dz0 which was to be proven.

sec.title: The case of coherent states
sec.p: Suppose that both wavefunctions are normalized coherent states concentrated near z0 = (x0, p0)z0=(x0,p0) and − z0−z0 at time tintin, that is we choose θ and ψ = ψz0ψ=ψz0 where(18)θ(x)=(1πℏ)N/4Tˆ(z0)e−1ℏ|x|2,ψ(x)=(1πℏ)N/4Tˆ(−z0)e−1ℏ|x|2; where Tˆ(z0)=e−iℏ(x0pˆ−p0xˆ) is the Heisenberg–Weyl operator. These states are minimum uncertainty states (they saturate the Heisenberg inequalities ΔxjΔpj ⩾ ½ℏΔxjΔpj⩾12ℏ). A standard calculation of Gaussian integrals shows that the scalar product of these states is(19)〈θ|ψ〉=e−1ℏ|z0|2. Let us calculate W(ϕ, ψ)W(ϕ,ψ). Using the translation formula (see de Gosson [16])(20)W(Tˆ(α)ϕ,Tˆ(β)ψ)(z)=e−iℏχαβ(z)W(ϕ,ψ)(z−12(α+β)) where χαβχαβ is the phase function defined by(21)χαβ(z) = ½σ(z, α − β) + σ(α, β)χαβ(z)=12σ(z,α−β)+σ(α,β) (σ the standard symplectic form). We thus haveW(ϕ,ψ)(z)=eiℏσ(z,z0)W(ξ0,ξ0)(z) where σ(z, z0) = px0 − p0xσ(z,z0)=px0−p0x and ξ0(x) = (πℏ) − N / 4e − |x|2 / ℏξ0(x)=(πℏ)−N/4e−|x|2/ℏ is the standard fiducial coherent state (Littlejohn [23]). Now, W(ξ0, ξ0) = Wξ0W(ξ0,ξ0)=Wξ0, the Wigner distribution of ξ0ξ0, which is given by(22)Wξ0(z)=(1πℏ)Ne−1ℏ|z|2,|z|2=|x|2+|p|2 (de Gosson [15,16], Littlejohn [23]). We thus conclude that(23)W(ϕ,ψ)(z)=(1πℏ)Neiℏσ(z,z0)e−1ℏ|z|2. Using the scalar product formula (19) we see that the complex probability distribution ρϕ, ψρϕ,ψ is given by(24)ρϕ,ψ(z)=(1πℏ)Neiℏσ(z,z0)e1ℏ|z0|2e−1ℏ|z|2. This formula shows that ρα, β(z)ρα,β(z) has an oscillatory behavior which is sharply peaked near the origin. We notice that since|ρϕ,ψ(z)|⩽(1πℏ)Ne1ℏ|z0|2e−1ℏ|z|2 the weak value 〈Aˆ〉weakϕ,ψ satisfies|〈Aˆ〉weakϕ,ψ|⩽∫R2N|ρϕ,ψ(z)||A(z)|dz=(1πℏ)Ne1ℏ|z0|2∫R2Ne−1ℏ|z|2|A(z)|dz⩽(1πℏ)Ne1ℏ|z0|2sup|A(z)|∫R2Ne−1ℏ|z|2dz. The integral in the third line is easy to evaluate; its value is (πℏ)N(πℏ)N hence we have the estimate(25)|〈Aˆ〉weakϕ,ψ|⩽e1ℏ|z0|2sup|A(z)|. This inequality shows that even if the observable A is small, the weak value can a priori take very large values provided that the phase space distance between both wavepackets ϕ, ψ is large; this is in strong contrast with what happens for the individual states |ϕ〉|ϕ〉 and |ψ〉|ψ〉, for which lead to the estimates|〈Aˆ〉ϕ|⩽sup|A(z)|,|〈Aˆ〉ψ|⩽sup|A(z)|; the relative phase space localization of these states does not play any role in these inequalities. We will shortly discuss non-trivial extensions of the superposition considered above in the discussion below.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Let us apply the phase space formalism to a discussion of the situation initially considered in [6,5] where at a time tintin an observable Aˆ is measured and a non-degenerate eigenvalue was found: |ψ(tin)〉=|Aˆ=a〉 (the pre-selected state); similarly at a later time tfintfin a measurement of another observable Bˆ yields |ϕ(tfin)〉=|Bˆ=b〉 (the post-selected state). Let t be some intermediate time: tin < t < tfintin<t<tfin. Following the time-symmetric approach to quantum mechanics (see the review in [4]), at this intermediate time the system is described by the two wavefunctions(26)ψt=Ut,tinHψ(tin),ϕt=Ut,tfinHϕ(tfin) where Ut,t′H=e−iHˆ(t−t′)/ℏ is the Schrödinger unitary evolution operator (Hˆ the quantum Hamiltonian). Notice that ϕtϕt travels backwards in time since t < tfint<tfin. The situation is thus the following: at any time t′ < tt′<t the system under consideration is in the state |ψt′〉=Ut′,tinH|ψ(tin)〉 and has Wigner distribution Wψt′Wψt′; at any time t″ > tt″>t the system is in the state |ϕt″〉=Ut″,tfinH|ϕ(tin)〉 and has Wigner distribution Wϕt′Wϕt′. But at time t it is the superposition |ψt〉 + |ϕt〉|ψt〉+|ϕt〉 of both states, and the Wigner distribution of this cat-like state is(27)W(ϕt + ψt) = Wϕt + Wψt + 2ReW(ϕt, ψt).W(ϕt+ψt)=Wϕt+Wψt+2ReW(ϕt,ψt). This equality shows the abrupt emergence at time t—and only at that time!—of the interference term 2Re W(ϕt, ψt)2ReW(ϕt,ψt), signaling a strong interaction between the states |ψt〉|ψt〉 and |ϕt〉|ϕt〉. Such an interaction is due to the wavelike nature of quantum mechanics, and is absent from classical mechanics. The appearance of interference terms described by the cross-Wigner transform is well known and considered as an asset in time-frequency analysis (e.g. radar theory, see Cohen [11], Auslander and Tolimieri [7]). It seems therefore that our approach could well open new perspectives in the topic of weak measurements and values, by importing robust techniques from these sciences (it is a fact, due mainly to historical and technical reasons, that the mathematical techniques related to the Wigner formalism have grown faster and are more sophisticated in signal theory and time-frequency analysis than they are in quantum mechanics, so a feedback seems to be more than welcome!).

How the weak values are related to sub-Planckian scales would also be interesting to investigate; the discussion in Zurek [31], and especially the results in Nicacio et al. [25] could certainly be useful in this context. These authors consider superpositions of an arbitrary number of Gaussian states, and study their motion under the action of arbitrary Hamiltonian flows. They show that the interference terms coming from the cross-Wigner transforms are always hyperbolic and survive the action of a thermal reservoir. While they mainly have in mind semiclassical dynamics, their approach could be implemented in the context of weak values. It is actually to a large extent sufficient to study the case of coherent states as in Section 2.3, because these states form an overcomplete set in the square-integrable functions. In fact, choosing an adequate lattice Λ of points z0z0 in phase space the functions Tˆ(z0)ξ0 (ξ0ξ0 the fiducial coherent state) form a Gabor frame (Folland [14], Gröchenig [17]) allowing to write an arbitrary pure state as a linear superposition of the states Tˆ(z0)ξ0. The net contribution of all cross-Wigner transforms of pairs (Tˆ(z0)ξ0,Tˆ(z1)ξ0) with z0 ≠ z1z0≠z1 is then the total interference leading to weak values (in [31] Zurek considers a “compass state” consisting of four terms Tˆ(z0)ξ0, of which he studies interference effects at the sub-Planckian scale; it would be interesting to interpret his results in terms of weak values).

There is another aspect of the theory of weak values we have not mentioned at all, if only because of lack of space and time. It is the possibility of reconstructing wave functions from weak values, as initiated in Lundeen et al. [24]. It turns out that the Wigner approach sketched in this Letter leads to useful formulas. For instance, on proves the following inversion formula (de Gosson [16, §9.4.2]): Let η be an arbitrary square integrable function such that 〈ϕ|γ〉 ≠ 0〈ϕ|γ〉≠0; then(28)ψ(x)=2N〈ϕ|γ〉∫R2NW(ϕ,ψ)(z0)TˆGR(z0)γ(x)dz0. We can reconstruct ψ from the knowledge of the weak value provided that we know γ and ϕ. This inversion formula together with the notion of mutually unbiased bases (MUB) could certainly play an important role in the reconstruction problem.

Another related approach that is interesting is that of Hiley [19] who uses algebraic ideas together with the Moyal formalism to study the weak values and their relation with the Bohmian theory of motion.
